intro: Seseli libanotis var. daucifolia, commonly known as the Lebanon thistle, is a flowering plant native to the Mediterranean region. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided leaves and small, yellowish flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or dry soils and is often found in mountainous areas. It has a taproot system and produces small, oval-shaped fruits called schizocarps. Due to its ornamental value and ecological importance, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens.
